title: 115_hr1122
content: The Act is known as the "Secondary Payer Advancement, Rationalization, and Clarification Act" or the "SPARC Act." It clarifies and rationalizes Medicare prescription drug secondary claims responsibility. The "SPARC Act" clarifies that a prescription drug plan is secondary payor to a primary drug plan until the primary plan settles the payment for an injury or illness. The "SPARC Act" establishes that a prescription drug plan is secondary to a primary drug plan until the primary plan settles payment for an injury or illness. Additionally, it limits certain parties from making prescription drug plans primary. The "SPARC Act" establishes that a prescription drug plan is secondary to a primary drug plan until the primary plan settles payment for an injury or illness. The agreement legally responsible for payment of a claim for a covered outpatient drug may not consider the individual's enrollment in a prescription drug plan or coverage for covered part D drugs. The Secretary cannot assert any claim on behalf or against a prescription drug plan, except for recovering amounts paid. The "SPARC Act" defines a primary drug plan as a group health plan or large group health plan responsible for covered part D drugs, excluding plans with fewer than 20 employees. The "SPARC Act" defines a primary drug plan as a group health plan or large group health plan responsible for covered part D drugs, excluding plans with fewer than 20 employees. An entity engaged in a business, trade, or profession is considered to have a self-insured plan if it carries its own risk. The "SPARC Act" defines a primary drug plan as a group health plan responsible for covered part D drugs. An entity is considered to have a self-insured plan if it carries its own risk. A prescription drug plan may waive provisions in the best interests of the program. The plan shall be subrogated to any right of payment for covered part D drugs. The "SPARC Act" defines a primary drug plan as a group health plan responsible for covered part D drugs. A subrogation claim may not be asserted by a prescription drug plan after 3 years of receiving notice of a payment for a covered part D drug. The subrogation claim is the exclusive legal remedy for the PDP sponsor and shall be reduced to account for procurement costs related to the claim. The Secretary shall provide coordination of benefits information to prescription drug plans in a convenient format within 15 days of receiving relevant information. Administrative costs related to recoveries under this subparagraph are not considered part of a prescription drug plan's expenses. The Secretary provides coordination of benefits information to prescription drug plans within 15 days. Administrative costs for recoveries are not part of a drug plan's expenses. Prescription drug plans must establish procedures to determine if costs for part D eligible individuals are reimbursed through insurance or other means. Coordination of benefits requires authorization for charging primary drug plans for covered part D drugs. The Secretary coordinates benefits for prescription drug plans within 15 days, with procedures in place to determine reimbursement for part D eligible individuals. Enrollees in a primary drug plan are responsible for medical payments until the plan terminates such responsibility. A web site is used to determine final reimbursement amounts. During enrollment in a prescription drug plan, the Secretary must notify the plan. The plan can provide a statement of covered drugs for reimbursement within 30 days of receiving the notice. Failure to provide the statement results in waiver of reimbursement. The prescription drug plan must provide a statement of covered drugs for reimbursement within 30 days of receiving the notice. Failure to do so results in waiver of reimbursement rights. The Secretary must include any covered part D drug identified by a prescription drug plan on the website for reimbursement. The Secretary may collect the reimbursement amount for covered part D drugs on behalf of a prescription drug plan. The Secretary may collect reimbursement amounts for covered part D drugs from individuals or primary drug plans as per section 1862(b)(2)(B)(vii). Amounts collected will be remitted to the prescription drug plan that enrolled the individual, with the Secretary retaining amounts as subsidy for the drugs. The effective date of this amendment is specified. The amendment made by subsection (a) applies to drugs dispensed more than 6 months after the enactment of this Act.
